user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t *local;
    int                                 status;

    local = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_timebase_table, *token);

    pthread_cancel(local->handler_thread);

    /*
    ** Delete the timer
    */
    if (local->assigned_signal != 0)
    {
        status = timer_delete(local->host_timerid);
        if (status < 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error deleting timer: %s\n", strerror(errno));
            return OS_TIMER_ERR_INTERNAL;
        }

        local->assigned_signal = 0;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimeBaseDelete_Impl:
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_t       handler_thread;
    pthread_mutex_t handler_mutex;
    timer_t         host_timerid;
    int             assigned_signal;
    sigset_t        sigset;
    sig_atomic_t    reset_flag;
    struct timespec softsleep;
} OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t
...
OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t OS_impl_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No other calls to the string.h string-handling functions (e.g. memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) appear in the provided function or related definitions. The remaining code lines are calls to pthread_cancel and timer_delete, simple assignments, array indexing via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, and structure/table declarations — none of which invoke string.h functions or perform pointer-based string/byte copies that could access beyond object bounds. The provided OS_DEBUG macro is defined as empty in the additional code, so in this build it does not introduce any string.h usage; therefore the only expression that may involve a string library (strerror(errno)) is the fragment listed above and should be investigated.
